dcterms:description.@value: Core classes and properties for the Brand Oracle (Brando) schema and ontology, an open, vendor-neutral vocabulary for AI-native Structured Governance of brands, lifecycle metadata, and integration with external tools and platforms. Brando repurposes Schema.org–style JSON-LD from a descriptive SEO layer into a prescriptive control layer that defines how a brand behaves in generative and agentic AI, protecting its identity across contexts and verbal/visual/audio tokens via machine-readable policies. The vocabulary extends schema:Brand, aligns with the GS1 Web Vocabulary and other product classification standards (e.g. UNSPSC, Google Product Taxonomy), and is designed to be published as a Brand Knowledge Graph that interoperates with existing DAM/CMS ecosystems and constrains LLM, agent, and multimodal outputs to on-brand, compliant behaviour.

rdfs:comment.@value: Abstract superclass for reusable brand expression tokens across verbal, visual, and audio modalities.
Core brand identity node extended with governance, architecture, and AI-ready semantics.
Activation context describing audience, channel, jurisdiction, and operational conditions for brand behaviour.
Reusable configuration of the brand's voice, language, and behavioural prompt rules.
Reusable configuration of the brand's visual system: logo, colour, typography, imagery, and motion.
Reusable configuration of the brand's sonic identity across voice, sonic logos, and audio cues.
Governance node encoding guard rails, refusals, compliance tags, and retrieval visibility.

Product or service category overlaid with brand-specific language, constraints, and hierarchy. May be aligned to GS1 Global Product Classification (GPC) and other standards such as UNSPSC and Google Product Taxonomy.
Time-bound marketing or communications campaign that may temporarily adjust brand rules.
Automated governance rule that reacts to monitored metrics or events to adjust brand behaviour.
Links a brand to one or more activation contexts in which it operates.
Attaches a verbal expression token defining how the brand speaks in this scope.
Attaches a visual expression token defining how the brand looks in this scope.
Attaches an audio expression token defining how the brand sounds in this scope.
Attaches governance, safety, and compliance policies to a brand or context.
Links a brand to its branded product or service category taxonomy nodes.
Links a brand to time-bound campaigns that may temporarily adjust rules and tokens.
Links a brand to automated governance rules and triggers.
The brand's core purpose and day-to-day reason for existing.
The aspirational future state the brand is working toward.
Foundational principles and beliefs that guide brand decisions and behaviours.
The core commitment or experience the brand guarantees to deliver.
How the brand positions itself in its category relative to alternatives and peers.
Longer-form narrative that explains the brand's origin, evolution, and purpose.
Summary of competitors, adjacent solutions, and how the brand differentiates.
Indicates whether a sub-brand inherits governance policies from its parent brand.
Structured definition of which expression tokens (verbal, visual, audio) are inherited and how.
The role this brand plays in the broader brand architecture (e.g. master brand, endorsed brand, sub-brand).
Description of how the brand is governed (e.g. centralised, federated, hybrid) for decision-making and approvals.
Strategic grouping of individuals who share needs or characteristics relevant to this context.
Persona-style archetypes representing typical users in this context.
Operational, legal, channel, regional, and use-case conditions encoded as a structured JSON payload.
Time window or schedule when this context, campaign, or policy is active, expressed as a structured JSON value.
Optional scoping for which products, categories, personas, or channels this node applies to.
Emotional texture and attitude of the brand's voice in this token.
Guidance on conversational patterns, pacing, and pronoun usage.
Preferences for grammar, sentence structure, and clarity.
Rules for how products, features, dates, and other entities are named and formatted.
Humanised brand-as-a-person description used to guide tone and behaviour.
Words and phrases that are encouraged in this verbal token.
Words and phrases that must not be used in this verbal token.
Core value propositions and ideas that should recur across outputs.
Primary tagline plus any sanctioned variants for this verbal token.
Reusable instruction block or template for priming language models.
Required behaviours and inclusions this verbal token must follow.
Behaviours and constructions this verbal token must never produce.
Canonical source URL for an asset associated with this expression token (e.g. avatar, badge, waveform).
Preview-friendly URL or data reference for displaying this token's associated asset.
Display name of the brand as it should appear in visual treatments.
Canonical reference URL to the primary logo asset or logo set.
URL pointing to full visual identity guidelines or design system documentation.
Structured description of the brand's colour system, including roles and values.
Typographic system including font families, weights, sizes, and hierarchy.
Core design tokens such as spacing, radius, and elevation.
Guidance on photography, illustration, and composition style.
Principles for animation, transitions, and micro-interactions.
Do's and don'ts for applying logos, colours, typography, and imagery.
URI pointing to the brand's sonic logo or audio mark.
Description of the desired voice profile for TTS or voice agents.
Standardised pronunciation notes (e.g. IPA or phonetic spelling) for brand names and key terms.
Guidance on rhythm, pacing, pausing, and expressiveness for spoken output.
Definitions of short sound cues used as confirmations, alerts, or transitions.
Do's and don'ts for when and how branded audio should be used.
URL pointing to canonical audio repositories or style guides.
Non-negotiable boundaries that AI systems must not cross.
Preferred patterns for declining or redirecting unsafe or out-of-scope requests.
Known edge cases and misuse patterns requiring caution or escalation.
Regulatory or legal tags such as GDPR, HIPAA, or FCA.
Description of human and/or automated steps for reviewing content and policy changes.
Rules for how often, by whom, and under what process policies are updated.
Governance precedence for this policy when multiple rules could apply.
Qualitative indicator of how easily this policy should be discoverable by AI systems.
Boolean flag indicating whether this policy may be indexed or retrieved by language models.
Qualitative or scored assessment of how well this content performs in vector search or RAG.
Name of a product or service category with associated brand tokens and rules.
Department-level categorisation within a product category.
Class-level categorisation within a department.
Specific item type within a category class.
Terms encouraged for this category, layered on top of brand-level approved terms.
Terms prohibited for this category, layered on top of brand-level prohibited terms.
Human-readable name of a marketing or communications campaign.
Central message or creative theme for the campaign.
Structured JSON describing temporary modifications to brand rules during this campaign.
Type of event or condition that activates this automation rule.
Structured JSON describing the metric being monitored, thresholds, and operators.
API endpoint or data source providing metrics or signals.
Structured JSON describing actions taken when trigger conditions are met.
GS1 Global Product Classification (GPC) brick code associated with this branded category.
Human-readable description of the GS1 Global Product Classification (GPC) brick associated with this branded category.
GTIN(s) for which this branded category or policy is applicable.
Links a branded category or policy to one or more GS1 Product nodes.

UNSPSC (United Nations Standard Products and Services Code) associated with this branded category or product grouping. Used to align brand-defined categories with procurement and B2B classification schemes.

Google Product Taxonomy category identifier associated with this branded category, typically used for shopping feeds, SEO, and retail media. Enables alignment between brand-level categories and Google Merchant Center classification.

Links a brand, token, context, campaign, or policy node to one or more canonical downloadable file assets (e.g. master logo packs, current guideline PDFs) represented as schema:MediaObject. Intended as a stable pointer to the most up-to-date creative files exposed by the Brand OS or DAM.

Links a brand, token, context, campaign, or policy node to non-canonical supporting creative files (e.g. templates, mockups, working documents, previous guideline versions) represented as schema:MediaObject. These files are helpful for production but are not the primary source-of-truth asset.

Links a brand, context, policy, campaign, or automation rule to the external tool or platform (e.g. Adobe GenStudio, Meta Ads Manager, Figma, CMS) that executes or consumes the corresponding brand rules. Typically points to a schema:SoftwareApplication node that describes the integration target.

Identifier for the corresponding object in an external tool or platform (e.g. brand, workspace, guideline set, ad account, or project ID). Used by Brand OS plugins to bind Brando Brand/Context/Policy/Campaign nodes to concrete entities in systems such as Adobe GenStudio, Meta Ads Manager, Figma, or internal CMSs.
Indicates how strongly a policy or automation rule must be applied at runtime. Typical values include 'mandatory', 'advisory', and 'conditional' and may be extended by implementations.

One or more lightweight tags describing the primary risk domains addressed by a policy or automation rule (e.g. 'regulatory', 'tone', 'brand-safety', 'platform-policy'). Intended for querying, reporting, and governance dashboards.
